q: What are the symptoms of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD)?
a: Some symptoms of ARPKD include underdeveloped lungs, high blood pressure, excessive peeing and thirst, problems with blood flow through the liver, and progressive loss of kidney function.

q: How is ARPKD caused?
a: ARPKD is caused by a genetic fault that disrupts the normal development of the kidneys and liver. It is usually inherited from the parents who carry a faulty version of the PKHD1 gene.

q: What are the treatment options for ARPKD?
a: There is currently no cure for ARPKD, but treatments such as breathing assistance, medication for high blood pressure, procedures to stop internal bleeding, and medications to control problems associated with kidney function loss can help manage the condition. In cases of kidney failure, dialysis or kidney transplant may be necessary.

q: What is the outlook for children with ARPKD?
a: The outlook for children with ARPKD can vary, but it is a severe condition and around 1 in 3 babies will die from severe breathing difficulties in the first 4 weeks after birth. However, with advances in treatments and a better understanding of the condition, the survival rate has improved, and many children with ARPKD are living into adulthood.

q: What is the role of the kidneys?
a: The main role of the kidneys is to filter out waste products from the blood before passing them out of the body as urine. The kidneys also help maintain blood pressure at a healthy level.

q: How is ARPKD different from autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)?
a: ARPKD is caused by a genetic alteration in the PKHD1 gene and is usually inherited from both parents. ADPKD, on the other hand, is a more common kidney disease and does not cause significantly reduced kidney function until adulthood. It can be inherited even when only one parent has a faulty gene, although this is rare.
